qas.question: Who printed the secret German-Soviet treaty in Britain?
Which world leader favored the publication of Nazi-Soviet Relations to be printed?
What was the description of the Soviet government in the world press in regards to the treaty and subsequent breaking of the treaty by germany?
Where was the Foreign Ministers conference held?
Who put the Nazi-Soviet Relations publication together?

answers.text: Raymond J. Sontag and James S. Beddie

qas.question: Who printed the public German-Soviet treaty in Britain?
Which world leader hated the publication of Nazi-Soviet Relations to be printed?
What wasn't the description of the Soviet government in the world press in regards to the treaty and subsequent breaking of the treaty by germany?
Where wasn't the Foreign Ministers conference held?

plausible_answers.text: Raymond J. Sontag and James S. Beddie

qas.question: Who destroyed the Nazi-Soviet Relations publication?

context: The treaty was published in the United States for the first time by the St. Louis Post-Dispatch on May 22, 1946, in Britain by <a0_0><b5_0>the Manchester Guardian<b5_0/><a0_0/>. It was also part of an official State Department publication, Nazi–Soviet Relations 1939–1941, edited by <a4_0><b9_0>Raymond J. Sontag and James S. Beddie<b9_0/><a4_0/> in January 1948. The decision to publish the key documents on German–Soviet relations, including the treaty and protocol, had been taken already in spring 1947. Sontag and Beddie prepared the collection throughout the summer of 1947. In November 1947, <a1_0><b6_0>President Truman<b6_0/><a1_0/> personally approved the publication but it was held back in view of the Foreign Ministers Conference in <a3_0><b8_0>London<b8_0/><a3_0/> scheduled for December. Since negotiations at that conference did not prove constructive from an American point of view, the document edition was sent to press. The documents made headlines worldwide. State Department officials counted it as a success: "The Soviet Government was caught <a2_0><b7_0>flat-footed<b7_0/><a2_0/> in what was the first effective blow from our side in a clear-cut propaganda war."
